title: Hyperparameter Tuning Techniques
text:
Objective
The objective of this project is to explore and test the performance of different hiperparameter tuning techniques for linear models, tree based models and neural networks. The aim is to show the use of each technique, determine their pros and cons and leave a functional code that can be used as a base for future projects.
These notes assume that you have previous knowledge on linear models, tree based models, neural networks, their parameters and hiperparameters, and model fitting. It is recommended that you go through some bibliography about these topics. Nonetheless, the notes include a brief introduction to each topic.
If you are new to these topics, you can go and check out:

StatQuest on Youtube
Julia Silge’s tidy tuesday
Tidy modeling with R

title: 1  Introduction
text:
The art of prediction has permeated every realm of human interest. From forecasting the weather, stock prices, and population growth to assessing couples’ compatibility, humanity’s desire to find certainty in the future is undeniable. It is this very desire that has led to the creation of data mining and machine learning.
Data mining refers to the art and science of intelligent analysis (Williams 2011). Through this process, intrinsic relationships, patterns, and knowledge embedded within the data are uncovered.




Williams, G. 2011. Data Mining with Rattle and r. Springer. https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4419-9890-3.

title: 2  Exploratory Analysis
text:
For this project, we will be using the data from from the California Housing dataset included in the scikit-learn library. The dataset contains 20,640 observations on housing prices in California. The dataset has 8 features and 1 target variable. The features are as follows:

MedInc: Median Income
HouseAge: Median House Age
AveRooms: Average Number of Rooms
AveBedrms: Average Number of Bedrooms
Population: Population
AveOccup: Average Occupancy
Latitude: Latitude
Longitude: Longitude

The target variable is:

MedHouseVal: Median House Value

title: References
text: Williams, G. 2011. Data Mining with Rattle and r. Springer. https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4419-9890-3.
